title: GiveWell - Malaria
text:
Preface
This project is my attempt to redo some of GiveWell’s calculations using the format of a Quarto book, and mostly using the programming language R instead of their method of Google spreadsheets and separate webpages.
This work is currently very incomplete, but I did notice two small (and ultimately insignificant) errors in two of their spreadsheets.

See 2.5 Percentage of targeted children interviewed for post-cycle surveys, Nigeria
See 5.2 Error in Original Calculations

title: 1  Source List 2019-2021
text: 1.1 Sources (2019)

title: 2  Source: 2021 post-cycle and post-round coverage
text:
The denominator in Table 14 is all eligible children present in the household at the time of cycle 4 whose caregivers responded to the question on coverage. For Table 17, it was the number of children who were present in the household during all cycles of the 2021 round, and whose caregivers gave information on coverage for all the cycles.
– Malaria Consortium, Response to GiveWell Questions, August 9, 2022 (unpublished)

title: 2  Source: 2021 post-cycle and post-round coverage
text:
2.4 Tidy Up the Data
The tables from the report are not in a tidy format with observations in rows and variables in columns, so we tidy the data and compine tables 15 and 16 since they both relate to Nigerian states.

2.4.1 Table 4
Table 4 is already tidy. All we do here is simplify the variable names.


Calculations
t4 <- read_excel("sources/2021/malaria-consortium-2021-table-04.xlsx",
                   col_types = c("text", "numeric", "numeric")) |>
  rename(state = 1, clusters = 2, targets = 3)




2.4.2 Table 14
For Table 14, we perform the following operations:

Simplify the variable names.
Create a new variable named country, and copy the data from the survey variable when n is empty.
For every empty value for country, fill it with the closest non-empty value above it.
Drop the rows where n is empty.
Separate country names from the parenthetical notes.
Delete the “)” at the end of the parenthetical notes.
Separate the c_interal variable into left_ci and right_ci, then make store them as numbers.



Calculations
t_14 <- read_excel("sources/2021/malaria-consortium-2021-table-14.xlsx",
                   col_types = c("text", "numeric", "numeric", "text")) |>
  rename(survey = 1, n = 2, p_hat = 3, c_interval = 4) |>
  mutate(country = case_when(is.na(n) ~ survey,
                              TRUE ~ NA),
         country = na.locf(country)) |>
  filter(!is.na(n)) |>
  separate_wider_delim(cols = country,
                       delim = "(",
                       names = c("country", "country_note"),
                       too_few = "align_start") |>
  mutate(country_note = str_sub(country_note, end = -2)) |>
  separate_wider_delim(cols = c_interval,
                       delim = '-',
                       names = c("left_ci", "right_ci")) |>
  mutate(left_ci = as.numeric(left_ci)/100,
         right_ci = as.numeric(right_ci)/100)




2.4.3 Table 15
For Table 15, we perform the following operations:

Simplify the variable names.
Create a new variable named country that is equal to “Nigeria,” because all of this data is from Nigera.
Create a new variable named state, and copy the data from the survey variable when n is empty.
For every empty value for state, fill it with the closest non-empty value above it.
Drop the rows where n is empty.
Separate the c_interal variable into left_ci and right_ci, then make store them as numbers.
This table relates to the Nigerian states that had 5 cycles, so create a variable to remember this.



Calculations
t_15 <- read_excel("sources/2021/malaria-consortium-2021-table-15.xlsx",
                   col_types = c("text", "numeric", "numeric", "text")) |>
  rename(survey = 1, n = 2, p_hat = 3, c_interval = 4) |>
  mutate(country = "Nigeria",
         state = case_when(is.na(n) ~ survey,
                              TRUE ~ NA),
         state = na.locf(state)) |>
  filter(!is.na(n)) |>
  separate_wider_delim(cols = c_interval,
                       delim = '-',
                       names = c("left_ci", "right_ci")) |>
  mutate(left_ci = as.numeric(left_ci)/100,
         right_ci = as.numeric(right_ci)/100) |>
  mutate(n_cycles = "5-cycle states")




2.4.4 Table 16
For Table 15, we perform the following operations:

Simplify the variable names.
Create a new variable named country that is equal to “Nigeria,” because all of this data is from Nigera.
Create a new variable named state, and copy the data from the survey variable when n is empty.
For every empty value for state, fill it with the closest non-empty value above it.
Drop the rows where n is empty.
Separate the c_interal variable into left_ci and right_ci, then make store them as numbers.
This table relates to the Nigerian states that had 4 cycles, so create a variable to remember this.



Calculations
t_16 <- read_excel("sources/2021/malaria-consortium-2021-table-16.xlsx",
                   col_types = c("text", "numeric", "numeric", "text")) |>
  rename(survey = 1, n = 2, p_hat = 3, c_interval = 4) |>
  mutate(country = "Nigeria",
         state = case_when(is.na(n) ~ survey,
                              TRUE ~ NA),
         state = na.locf(state)) |>
  filter(!is.na(n)) |>
  separate_wider_delim(cols = c_interval,
                       delim = '-',
                       names = c("left_ci", "right_ci")) |>
  mutate(left_ci = as.numeric(left_ci)/100,
         right_ci = as.numeric(right_ci)/100) |>
  mutate(n_cycles = "4-cycle states")




2.4.5 Bind Tables 15 and 16
Tables 15 and 16 both related to Nigerian states. It makes sense to bind them.


Calculations
t_1516 <- t_15 |>
  bind_rows(t_16)
crumbs: 2  Source: 2021 post-cycle and post-round coverage

title: 2  Source: 2021 post-cycle and post-round coverage
section: 2.5 Percentage of targeted children interviewed for post-cycle surveys, Nigeria
text:
2.5 Percentage of targeted children interviewed for post-cycle surveys, Nigeria
This subsection mirrors the calculations at the bottom of GiveWell’s spreadsheet.


Calculations
gw1516 <- t_1516 |>
  left_join(t4, join_by(state)) |>
  group_by(survey) |>
  summarise(sampled = sum(n), targeted = sum(targets)) |>
  mutate(percent_targeted_interviewed = label_percent(accuracy = 1)(sampled/targeted)) |>
  filter(survey != "EoR: cycle 5")

gw1516|>
  kable(digits = 1, format.args = list(big.mark = ","))





survey
sampled
targeted
percent_targeted_interviewed




EoC: cycle 1
7,375
9,775
75%


EoC: cycle 2
25,497
25,150
101%


EoC: cycle 3
27,271
26,900
101%


EoC: cycle 4
24,988
26,900
93%





Note that only the state with five cycles–Kogi, Nasarawa, and Plateau–had EoC: cycle 1.
There is one discrepany between this table and GiveWell’s spreadsheet cell C82. This is that EoC: cycle 2 in the targetted column as 26900. However, this analysis does not count those targetted in Borno since there is no cycle 2 listed for Borno in Table 16 from Malaria Consortium, 2021 SMC coverage report, Burkina Faso, Chad, Mozambique, Nigeria, Togo, and Uganda.
crumbs: 2  Source: 2021 post-cycle and post-round coverage

title: 2  Source: 2021 post-cycle and post-round coverage
text:
2.6 Save the tidy data


Calculations
save(list = c('t_14', 't_15', 't_16', 't_1516', 'gw1516'), file="data/2021/post-cycle-coverage.R")
crumbs: 2  Source: 2021 post-cycle and post-round coverage

title: 5  Calculation: Nigeria 2021 post-cycle coverage
text:
5.1 Nigeria post-cycle coverage, total, weighted by target population (added by GiveWell)
The calculation from this sheet relies on target populations from Table 8 from Malaria Consortium, 2021 SMC coverage report, Burkina Faso, Chad, Mozambique, Nigeria, Togo, and Uganda. We only need the target populations for children 5 and under, so we choose that subset of the table.
This is using the target population from Nasarawa[2] row.
If we changed this to the 952,480 target population, which was the original estimate, then the total target population for Nigeria would match that reported in Table 1, Pg. 11 (8,399,151): 8,041,804 + (952,480 - 595,133) = 8,399,151
We are using the updated figure, because it is more accurate. Below, we change the name of Nasarawa2 -> Nasarawa. In the join operation later, the old numbers corresponding to Nasawawa1 will be dropped.
Calculations
t_8 = read_excel("sources/2021/malaria-consortium-2021-table-08.xlsx", 
                 sheet = "Sheet1", col_names = FALSE, 
                 skip = 3, n_max = 28) |>
  select(1:4) |>
  rename(country = 1, state = 2, age_group = 3, target_pop = 4) |>
  mutate(country = na.locf(country),
         state = na.locf(state)) |>
  filter(age_group == '3–59 months') |>
  select(-age_group) |>
  mutate(state = case_when(state == 'Nasarawa2' ~ 'Nasarawa',
                           TRUE ~ state)) |>
  suppressMessages()
We then join the target population numbers to our data from tables 15 and 16. Then we calculate summary statistics, both for the 4-cycle and 5-cycle groups, then grand totals.
Calculations
load("data/2021/post-cycle-coverage.R")
t_1516 |>
  left_join(t_8, join_by(country, state)) |>
  select(state, target_pop, p_hat, n_cycles, survey) |>
  pivot_wider(id_cols = c(state, target_pop, n_cycles),
              names_from = survey,
              values_from = p_hat) |>
  group_by(n_cycles) |>
  gt() |>
  fmt_percent(
    columns = 3:8,
    decimals = 1
  ) |>
  fmt_number(columns = 2, decimals = 0) |>
  sub_missing() |>
  summary_rows(
    columns = target_pop,
    fns = list('Group Total' = ~ sum(.)),
    fmt = ~fmt_number(., decimals = 0)
  ) |>
  summary_rows(
    columns = 3:8,
    fns = list('Group Total' = ~ weighted.mean(x=., w=target_pop, na.rm = TRUE)),
    fmt = ~fmt_percent(., decimals = 1)
  ) |>
  grand_summary_rows(
    columns = target_pop,
    fns = list('Total' = ~ sum(.)),
    fmt = ~fmt_number(., decimals = 0)
  ) |>
  grand_summary_rows(
    columns = 3:8,
    fns = list('Total' = ~ weighted.mean(x=., w=target_pop, na.rm = TRUE)),
    fmt = ~fmt_percent(., decimals = 1)
  )









state
target_pop

title: 5  Calculation: Nigeria 2021 post-cycle coverage
text:
The target population for Nasarawa was overestimated in 2021. The target population for Nasarawa was revised downwards after cycle 2 and administrative coverage re-estimated.
–Malaria Consortium, 2021 SMC coverage report, Burkina Faso, Chad, Mozambique, Nigeria, Togo, and Uganda. Pg. 31

title: 5  Calculation: Nigeria 2021 post-cycle coverage
text:
5.2 Error in Original Calculations
There is one discrepancy between this table and GiveWell’s spreadsheet cells F7, F8, and F14. This is because the original spreadsheet has the incorrect forumla in F7. The formula it ought to have in F7 is =C34. The correct value in cell F7 is 90.4%. This incorrect value then affects the totals in F8 and F14.

title: 5  Calculation: Nigeria 2021 post-cycle coverage

title: 3  Source: 2021 SMC cycles received per child
text:
3.1 Table 25: Proportions of eligible children (3–59 months) who received day 1 SPAQ by community distributors by number of cycles during 2021 (EoR survey), by country
Because of the merged cells and combined variables, we tidy this table up before displaying it.
Calculations
t_25 <-read_excel("sources/2021/malaria-consortium-2021-table-25.xlsx",
           col_types = c("text", "numeric", "numeric", "text")) |>
  rename(cycle = 1, n = 2, p_hat = 3, c_interval = 4) |>
  mutate(country = case_when(is.na(p_hat) ~ cycle,
                              TRUE ~ NA),
         country = na.locf(country),
         n = c(NA, na.locf(n))) |>
  filter(!is.na(p_hat)) |>
  separate_wider_delim(cols = country,
                       delim = "(",
                       names = c("country", "country_note"),
                       too_few = "align_start") |>
  mutate(country_note = str_sub(country_note, end = -2)) |>
  separate_wider_delim(cols = c_interval,
                       delim = '-',
                       names = c("left_ci", "right_ci")) |>
  mutate(left_ci = as.numeric(left_ci)/100,
         right_ci = as.numeric(right_ci)/100)

t_25 |>
  kable(caption = "Table 25")

crumbs: 3  Source: 2021 SMC cycles received per child

title: Source: 2021 SMC cycles received per child
text:
Because of the merged cells and combined variables, we tidy this table up before displaying it.


Calculations
t_25 <-read_excel("sources/2021/malaria-consortium-2021-table-25.xlsx",
           col_types = c("text", "numeric", "numeric", "text")) |>
  rename(cycle = 1, n = 2, p_hat = 3, c_interval = 4) |>
  mutate(country = case_when(is.na(p_hat) ~ cycle,
                              TRUE ~ NA),
         country = na.locf(country),
         n = c(NA, na.locf(n))) |>
  filter(!is.na(p_hat)) |>
  separate_wider_delim(cols = country,
                       delim = "(",
                       names = c("country", "country_note"),
                       too_few = "align_start") |>
  mutate(country_note = str_sub(country_note, end = -2)) |>
  separate_wider_delim(cols = c_interval,
                       delim = '-',
                       names = c("left_ci", "right_ci")) |>
  mutate(left_ci = as.numeric(left_ci)/100,
         right_ci = as.numeric(right_ci)/100)

t_25 |>
  kable(caption = "Table 25")

title: 4  Source: Targetted Populations
text:
4.1 Targetted Population by Country
Calculations
t_1 <- read_excel("sources/2021/malaria-consortium-2021-table-01.xlsx", 
                 sheet = "Sheet1", n_max = 8) |>
  separate_wider_delim(cols = 1,
                       delim = "(",
                       too_many = "drop",
                       names = "country") |>
  separate_wider_delim(cols = 3,
                       delim = "(",
                       too_many = "drop",
                       names = "target_pop") |>
  select(country, target_pop) |>
  mutate(target_pop = as.numeric(gsub(",","",target_pop)))

t_1 |> gt()

target_pop

t_1 <- read_excel("sources/2021/malaria-consortium-2021-table-01.xlsx", 
                 sheet = "Sheet1", n_max = 8) |>
  separate_wider_delim(cols = 1,
                       delim = "(",
                       too_many = "drop",
                       names = "country") |>
  separate_wider_delim(cols = 3,
                       delim = "(",
                       too_many = "drop",
                       names = "target_pop") |>
  select(country, target_pop) |>
  mutate(target_pop = as.numeric(gsub(",","",target_pop)))

title: 4  Source: Targetted Populations
text:
4.2 Nigeria
This is using the target population from Nasarawa[2] row.

The target population for Nasarawa was overestimated in 2021. The target population for Nasarawa was revised downwards after cycle 2 and administrative coverage re-estimated.
–Malaria Consortium, 2021 SMC coverage report, Burkina Faso, Chad, Mozambique, Nigeria, Togo, and Uganda. Pg. 31

If we changed this to the 952,480 target population, which was the original estimate, then the total target population for Nigeria would match that reported in Table 1, Pg. 11 (8,399,151): \[8,041,804 + (952,480 - 595,133) = 8,399,151\]
We are using the updated figure, because it is more accurate.


Calculations
t_8 = read_excel("sources/2021/malaria-consortium-2021-table-08.xlsx", 
                 sheet = "Sheet1", col_names = FALSE, 
                 skip = 3, n_max = 28) |>
  select(1:4) |>
  rename(country = 1, state = 2, age_group = 3, target_pop = 4) |>
  mutate(country = na.locf(country),
         state = na.locf(state)) |>
  filter(age_group == '3–59 months') |>
  select(-age_group) |>
  mutate(state = case_when(state == 'Nasarawa2' ~ 'Nasarawa',
                           TRUE ~ state)) |>
  suppressMessages()

t_8 |> gt()

save(list = c('t_1', 't_8'), file="data/2021/target_populations.R")
